elements.content: When 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone molecule (1m2p) interacts with the T[Ni(CN)4] layer, its carbonyl π bond homolytically disrupts and forms a coordination bond at the axial positions for the metal T, and hybrid inorganic–organic solids of formula unit T(L)2[Ni(CN)4], with T = Mn, Co, Ni, are obtained. The formed solids crystallize with a monoclinic unit cell in the C2/m space group where the metal T is found with octahedral coordination to four N ends of CN groups from a given layer and to two oxygen atoms from the organic ligands, while the inner metal (Ni) preserves its square planar coordination. In the interlayer region, the organic molecules achieve unusual planarity and are stacked through dipole–dipole interactions in a head-to-tail configuration to form a chain of molecular pillars. From such interactions, 3D pillared hybrid solids result. Upon the charge donation to the metal by oxygen atom from 1m2p, the latter becomes an organic radical whose SOMO frontier orbital has a strong π character, associated with an essentially planar structure. The unpaired electron is delocalized between neighboring C and N atoms at the ligand ring plane, and it is featured by an outstanding broad absorption band in the near-IR region. For Ni, the metal of highest polarizing power within the considered series, the existence of π overlapping interaction between organic ligand molecules leads to ferromagnetic ordering at low temperature, with T C = 10.07 K. For Mn and Co, related to the lower metal electron-withdrawing ability, the materials maintain the weak antiferromagnetic character resulting from the interaction between T metals in the layer −T–NC–Ni–CN–T– chains.
elements.clean_text: When 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone molecule (1m2p) interacts with the T[Ni(CN)4] layer, its carbonyl π bond homolytically disrupts and forms a coordination bond at the axial positions for the metal T, and hybrid inorganic-organic solids of formula unit T(L)2[Ni(CN)4], with T = Mn, Co, Ni, are obtained. The formed solids crystallize with a monoclinic unit cell in the C2/m space group where the metal T is found with octahedral coordination to four N ends of CN groups from a given layer and to two oxygen atoms from the organic ligands, while the inner metal (Ni) preserves its square planar coordination. In the interlayer region, the organic molecules achieve unusual planarity and are stacked through dipole-dipole interactions in a head-to-tail configuration to form a chain of molecular pillars. From such interactions, 3D pillared hybrid solids result. Upon the charge donation to the metal by oxygen atom from 1m2p, the latter becomes an organic radical whose SOMO frontier orbital has a strong π character, associated with an essentially planar structure. The unpaired electron is delocalized between neighboring C and N atoms at the ligand ring plane, and it is featured by an outstanding broad absorption band in the near-IR region. For Ni, the metal of highest polarizing power within the considered series, the existence of π overlapping interaction between organic ligand molecules leads to ferromagnetic ordering at low temperature, with T C = 10.07 K. For Mn and Co, related to the lower metal electron-withdrawing ability, the materials maintain the weak antiferromagnetic character resulting from the interaction between T metals in the layer -T-NC-Ni-CN-T- chains.

elements.content: 1-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone (1m2p), also known as N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone, is a dipolar aprotic solvent widely used in organic chemistry for its ability to dissolve many chemicals. It is also applied for pure hydrocarbon recovery in the petrochemical industry, in the surface treatment of textiles, and in the formulation of drugs in the pharmaceutical industry, among many others. In the past decade 1m2p has received certain attention in nanotechnologies and materials science by its large surface tension (γ), above 40 mJ/m2, which minimizes the required exfoliation energy in 2D solids, e.g., graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides, and transition metal oxides. Such a feature also explains its application in the preparation of carbon nanotubes suspensions, for instance.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

1-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone (1m2p), also known as N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone, is a dipolar aprotic solvent widely used in organic chemistry for its ability to dissolve many chemicals. It is also applied for pure hydrocarbon recovery in the petrochemical industry, in the surface treatment of textiles, and in the formulation of drugs in the pharmaceutical industry, among many others. In the past decade 1m2p has received certain attention in nanotechnologies and materials science by its large surface tension (γ), above 40 mJ/m2, which minimizes the required exfoliation energy in 2D solids, e.g., graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides, and transition metal oxides. Such a feature also explains its application in the preparation of carbon nanotubes suspensions, for instance.

elements.content: 1m2p is a cyclic amide with two lone pairs of electrons on the amide carbonyl oxygen. It has a more stable amide C–N bond compared to an unsubstituted pyrrolidone due to the electron-donating effect of the N-substituted methyl group, which favors the resonance stabilization of the amide group through increasing C–N double bond character and simultaneously weakening C–O double bond character. In this way, the tertiary nature of the amide group concentrates charge density on oxygen from the carbonyl group and increases the basicity of the amide carbonyl group. It promotes a stronger tendency to coordinate to Lewis acidic sites and form coordination complexes with metals compared with other amides. The existence of such complexes is well documented for the rare-earth metals (Ln) series, particularly those involving polyoxometalate anions and [Ln(1m2p) x ]3+ cations. The information available for 1m2p complexes with the first series of transition metals is relatively limited, although the complexes with this ligand could be of importance in biological chemistry as prototypes for coordination compounds with lactams type ligands. To our knowledge, planar structures for 1m2p are seldom reported.
elements.clean_text: 1m2p is a cyclic amide with two lone pairs of electrons on the amide carbonyl oxygen. It has a more stable amide C-N bond compared to an unsubstituted pyrrolidone due to the electron-donating effect of the N-substituted methyl group, which favors the resonance stabilization of the amide group through increasing C-N double bond character and simultaneously weakening C-O double bond character. In this way, the tertiary nature of the amide group concentrates charge density on oxygen from the carbonyl group and increases the basicity of the amide carbonyl group. It promotes a stronger tendency to coordinate to Lewis acidic sites and form coordination complexes with metals compared with other amides. The existence of such complexes is well documented for the rare-earth metals (Ln) series, particularly those involving polyoxometalate anions and [Ln(1m2p) x ]3+ cations. The information available for 1m2p complexes with the first series of transition metals is relatively limited, although the complexes with this ligand could be of importance in biological chemistry as prototypes for coordination compounds with lactams type ligands. To our knowledge, planar structures for 1m2p are seldom reported.

elements.content: The family of 2D solids, T[M(CN)4], where M = Ni, Pd, Pt, and T is a divalent transition metal, is highly attractive for coordination chemistry because the intercalation of appropriate ligands leads to the availability of nanosized interlayered spaces where a number of guest molecules can be accommodated. Such guest species modify the material electronic structure and its physical properties. It is also known that the intrinsic switchable nature of these solids makes them excellent platforms for a new generation of sensory and memory materials based on the existence of host–guest chemistry. Axial positions for the metal T in the layer become available for coordinating interactions usually after removing sequentially enclathrated and coordinated water molecules. In the search for an easier synthesis, 1m2p was initially intended as a solvent in order to obtain isolated layers of these 2D solids. However, on the 1m2p molecule interaction with T[Ni(CN)4] layer, its carbonyl π bond homolitically disrupts and the coordination bond at the axial positions for the metal T is formed with the oxygen atom from the original carbonyl group, resulting in the formation of 3D solids of formula unit T(L)2[Ni(CN)4], where T = Mn, Co, Ni and L = activated 1m2p molecule. Activation of 1m2p molecule is also reflected in the planarity that the molecule achieves through the elongation of one C–C bond within the ring and its paramagnetic character. The obtained hybrid solids were characterized from chemical analyses, infrared (IR) and UV–vis spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric (TG) and magnetic measurements. Their crystal structure was solved and refined from powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data. The unexpected 1m2p reactivity toward layered T[Ni(CN)4] describes an unidentified T Lewis acidity which nonetheless exhibits subtle differences depending on the nature of the T metal. To the best of our knowledge, no previous evidence about the mentioned solvent modification at ambient pressure and temperature has been reported. The formed hybrid inorganic–organic solids, T(L)2[Ni(CN)4], and their properties are also new results, not previously discussed. Transformation of organic molecules from diamagnetic to radical upon coordination opens the door to an unexplored new panorama for T[Ni(CN)4] layers in whose galleries magnetic phenomena can take place.
elements.clean_text: The family of 2D solids, T[M(CN)4], where M = Ni, Pd, Pt, and T is a divalent transition metal, is highly attractive for coordination chemistry because the intercalation of appropriate ligands leads to the availability of nanosized interlayered spaces where a number of guest molecules can be accommodated. Such guest species modify the material electronic structure and its physical properties. It is also known that the intrinsic switchable nature of these solids makes them excellent platforms for a new generation of sensory and memory materials based on the existence of host-guest chemistry. Axial positions for the metal T in the layer become available for coordinating interactions usually after removing sequentially enclathrated and coordinated water molecules. In the search for an easier synthesis, 1m2p was initially intended as a solvent in order to obtain isolated layers of these 2D solids. However, on the 1m2p molecule interaction with T[Ni(CN)4] layer, its carbonyl π bond homolitically disrupts and the coordination bond at the axial positions for the metal T is formed with the oxygen atom from the original carbonyl group, resulting in the formation of 3D solids of formula unit T(L)2[Ni(CN)4], where T = Mn, Co, Ni and L = activated 1m2p molecule. Activation of 1m2p molecule is also reflected in the planarity that the molecule achieves through the elongation of one C-C bond within the ring and its paramagnetic character. The obtained hybrid solids were characterized from chemical analyses, infrared (IR) and UV-vis spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric (TG) and magnetic measurements. Their crystal structure was solved and refined from powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data. The unexpected 1m2p reactivity toward layered T[Ni(CN)4] describes an unidentified T Lewis acidity which nonetheless exhibits subtle differences depending on the nature of the T metal. To the best of our knowledge, no previous evidence about the mentioned solvent modification at ambient pressure and temperature has been reported. The formed hybrid inorganic-organic solids, T(L)2[Ni(CN)4], and their properties are also new results, not previously discussed. Transformation of organic molecules from diamagnetic to radical upon coordination opens the door to an unexplored new panorama for T[Ni(CN)4] layers in whose galleries magnetic phenomena can take place.

elements.content: The T[Ni(CN)4] layered material was prepared by the precipitation method mixing aqueous solutions of K2[Ni(CN)4] and T2+ sulfate of the involved metals. The formed precipitate was aged for at least three days and then washed several times with distilled water to remove all the accompanying species and finally dried in air until constant weight. The obtained 2D solid was characterized from XRD, IR, and TG data. The preparative routes, crystal structures, and spectroscopic and thermal properties of these layered materials are documented. Samples of T[Ni(CN)4] were suspended in 1m2p at a concentration of 0.01 mg/mL and sonicated for 1 h to favor the exfoliation process. On aging, a hybrid inorganic–organic solid precipitates. The obtained fine powder was separated by centrifugation, washed with fresh 1m2p, and then characterized by chemical analyses, XRD, IR, UV–vis, TG, and magnetic data.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

The T[Ni(CN)4] layered material was prepared by the precipitation method mixing aqueous solutions of K2[Ni(CN)4] and T2+ sulfate of the involved metals. The formed precipitate was aged for at least three days and then washed several times with distilled water to remove all the accompanying species and finally dried in air until constant weight. The obtained 2D solid was characterized from XRD, IR, and TG data. The preparative routes, crystal structures, and spectroscopic and thermal properties of these layered materials are documented. Samples of T[Ni(CN)4] were suspended in 1m2p at a concentration of 0.01 mg/mL and sonicated for 1 h to favor the exfoliation process. On aging, a hybrid inorganic-organic solid precipitates. The obtained fine powder was separated by centrifugation, washed with fresh 1m2p, and then characterized by chemical analyses, XRD, IR, UV-vis, TG, and magnetic data.

elements.content: IR spectra were recorded diluting the solid in pressed KBr disks. The XRD powder patterns were collected at room conditions using a D8 Advance diffractometer (from Bruker) and CuKα1 radiation. The crystal structures were solved ab initio by Patterson methods using the program SHELXL from extracted intensities according to the Le Bail method. The structural refinement from these XRD powder patterns was performed with the Rietveld method using the FullProf program and pseudo-Voigt peak shape function. Peak profiles were calculated within 10 times the full width at half-maximum (fwhm). The background was modeled by a third-order polynomial. The interatomic Ni–C and C–N distances were constrained to take values within certain limits considering results from the structural study of the parent T[Ni(CN)4] layered solids.
elements.clean_text: IR spectra were recorded diluting the solid in pressed KBr disks. The XRD powder patterns were collected at room conditions using a D8 Advance diffractometer (from Bruker) and CuKα1 radiation. The crystal structures were solved ab initio by Patterson methods using the program SHELXL from extracted intensities according to the Le Bail method. The structural refinement from these XRD powder patterns was performed with the Rietveld method using the FullProf program and pseudo-Voigt peak shape function. Peak profiles were calculated within 10 times the full width at half-maximum (fwhm). The background was modeled by a third-order polynomial. The interatomic Ni-C and C-N distances were constrained to take values within certain limits considering results from the structural study of the parent T[Ni(CN)4] layered solids.

elements.content: The magnetic data were collected in the 2–300 K temperature range using MPMS-5 SQUID. The magnetization curves under applied magnetic field were recorded up to 4 T. The sample temperature was varied at a rate of 1 K·min–1, both on heating and on cooling. Experimental susceptibilities (the effective magnetic moments per formula unit) were corrected for diamagnetism of the constituent atoms by the use of Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic data were collected in the 2-300 K temperature range using MPMS-5 SQUID. The magnetization curves under applied magnetic field were recorded up to 4 T. The sample temperature was varied at a rate of 1 K⋅min-1, both on heating and on cooling. Experimental susceptibilities (the effective magnetic moments per formula unit) were corrected for diamagnetism of the constituent atoms by the use of Pascal's constants.

elements.content:
Optimization of ligand structure for Figure was made with free software from ACD/Laboratories, a trademark of Advanced Chemistry Development, Inc., Copyright 1997–2008.

Results and DiscussionNature of the Formed Hybrid Solids

According to IR and TG data (see the ), the starting layered solids T[Ni(CN)4]·xH2O to be exfoliated correspond to the L0 phase (x = 6, orthorhombic unit cell, Pnma space group) for these 2D materials. Thus, initially two coordinated water molecules are found at the axial positions of metal T which support a network of hydrogen-bonded water molecules and maintain together neighboring layers. The precipitate obtained from the T[Ni(CN)4] suspension in 1m2p preserves the layered structure of the initial solid. The recorded IR spectra, which show ν(CN) and δ(Ni–CN) vibrations with minimal frequency shift, suggest that the chains structure of the layered solid −T–NC–Ni–CN–T– is preserved (Table , Figure )
elements.clean_text:
Optimization of ligand structure for Figure  was made with free software from ACD/Laboratories, a trademark of Advanced Chemistry Development, Inc., Copyright 1997-2008.

Results and Discussion

Nature of the Formed Hybrid Solids

According to IR and TG data (see the ), the starting layered solids T[Ni(CN)4]⋅xH2O to be exfoliated correspond to the L0 phase (x = 6, orthorhombic unit cell, Pnma space group) for these 2D materials. Thus, initially two coordinated water molecules are found at the axial positions of metal T which support a network of hydrogen-bonded water molecules and maintain together neighboring layers. The precipitate obtained from the T[Ni(CN)4] suspension in 1m2p preserves the layered structure of the initial solid. The recorded IR spectra, which show ν(CN) and δ(Ni-CN) vibrations with minimal frequency shift, suggest that the chains structure of the layered solid -T-NC-Ni-CN-T- is preserved (Table , Figure )

elements.content: The IR spectra of the formed hybrid compounds correspond to slightly hydrated solids because the ν(O–H) absorption bands appear above the 3200 cm–1 wavenumber region, being different however from those observed in the initial 2D solid. This is confirmed by the obtained TG curves, which exhibit a smooth weight loss (less than 3%) in the dehydration region (see the ). IR spectra provide a conclusive clue, through the frequency shift for the ν(CO) vibration, on the nature of the formed coordination bond between the metal (T) and the organic molecule. In 1m2p this vibration is observed at 1688 cm–1, while in the precipitate it is found at 1662, 1668, and 1671 cm–1, for Mn, Co, and Ni, respectively (Table ). Such negative frequency shift results from a weakening of the bond between the carbon and oxygen atoms by the charge donation to the metal. The carbonyl π bond is homolitically disrupted (discussed below). Coordination bonding is accompanied by certain charge redistribution within the ring and from the methyl group through the N atom, which is detected as slight frequency shifts for the ligand molecule (Table ). Such coordination mode had been previously identified at 573 K on aluminum nitride surface, but not at room temperature. Lewis acidic sites found in the T[Ni(CN)4] layer and the resonance stabilization of the amide group due to the electron-donating effect of the methyl group seem to play a synergistic role in the coordination of the organic ligand. The latter is supported by the occurrence of a new ν(CO) band at 1321 cm–1, which is a distinctive characteristic of carbonyl bridging to a Lewis acid.
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra of the formed hybrid compounds correspond to slightly hydrated solids because the ν(O-H) absorption bands appear above the 3200 cm-1 wavenumber region, being different however from those observed in the initial 2D solid. This is confirmed by the obtained TG curves, which exhibit a smooth weight loss (less than 3%) in the dehydration region (see the ). IR spectra provide a conclusive clue, through the frequency shift for the ν(CO) vibration, on the nature of the formed coordination bond between the metal (T) and the organic molecule. In 1m2p this vibration is observed at 1688 cm-1, while in the precipitate it is found at 1662, 1668, and 1671 cm-1, for Mn, Co, and Ni, respectively (Table ). Such negative frequency shift results from a weakening of the bond between the carbon and oxygen atoms by the charge donation to the metal. The carbonyl π bond is homolitically disrupted (discussed below). Coordination bonding is accompanied by certain charge redistribution within the ring and from the methyl group through the N atom, which is detected as slight frequency shifts for the ligand molecule (Table ). Such coordination mode had been previously identified at 573 K on aluminum nitride surface, but not at room temperature. Lewis acidic sites found in the T[Ni(CN)4] layer and the resonance stabilization of the amide group due to the electron-donating effect of the methyl group seem to play a synergistic role in the coordination of the organic ligand. The latter is supported by the occurrence of a new ν(CO) band at 1321 cm-1, which is a distinctive characteristic of carbonyl bridging to a Lewis acid.

elements.content: The very large decrease for ν(CO) vibration when T = Ni (1652 cm–1) is determined by the ability of this metal to subtract charge from the ligand molecule. Such ability is related to the metal polarizing power (Ze/r2) which for Ni is the highest one within the series. Besides the C–O bond, as a result of this subtle difference among the involved T metals, resonance stabilization rearrangement within the amide C–N bond (C′N)1m2p shows slight differences. In the case of T = Ni and Co, ν(CO) and ν(C′N)1m2p vibrations appear resolved in two different bands and as a shoulder, respectively, contrary to the one observed for T = Mn and free 1m2p spectra where they are observed as a broad single band.
elements.clean_text: The very large decrease for ν(CO) vibration when T = Ni (1652 cm-1) is determined by the ability of this metal to subtract charge from the ligand molecule. Such ability is related to the metal polarizing power (Ze/r2) which for Ni is the highest one within the series. Besides the C-O bond, as a result of this subtle difference among the involved T metals, resonance stabilization rearrangement within the amide C-N bond (C'N)1m2p shows slight differences. In the case of T = Ni and Co, ν(CO) and ν(C'N)1m2p vibrations appear resolved in two different bands and as a shoulder, respectively, contrary to the one observed for T = Mn and free 1m2p spectra where they are observed as a broad single band.

elements.content: The frequency for the ν(CN) vibration from tetracyanonickellate building block (TCN) within the layer is also a sensor for the coordination bond formation at the metal T axial positions. The charge donated by the axial ligands modifies the metal ability to subtract charge from the CN bridges in the layer, and this is detected as a slight shift to higher frequency for the ν(CN) vibration. For the considered series, the replacement of water by 1m2p as axial ligands only produces a small frequency shift for this vibration (Table ). It seems the amount of charge donated by the organic ligand or the water molecule to the metal T is quite similar.
elements.clean_text: The frequency for the ν(CN) vibration from tetracyanonickellate building block (TCN) within the layer is also a sensor for the coordination bond formation at the metal T axial positions. The charge donated by the axial ligands modifies the metal ability to subtract charge from the CN bridges in the layer, and this is detected as a slight shift to higher frequency for the ν(CN) vibration. For the considered series, the replacement of water by 1m2p as axial ligands only produces a small frequency shift for this vibration (Table ). It seems the amount of charge donated by the organic ligand or the water molecule to the metal T is quite similar.

IR spectra for 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, Ni(H2O)2[Ni(CN)4]·4H2O, and Ni(L)2[Ni(CN)4]. Analogous sets of spectra were obtained for Mn and Co (see the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: 1  IR spectra for 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, Ni(H2O)2[Ni(CN)4]⋅4H2O, and Ni(L)2[Ni(CN)4]. Analogous sets of spectra were obtained for Mn and Co (see the Supporting Information).

elements.content: UV–vis spectra suggest that in the obtained precipitate the T atoms preserve the octahedral coordination, which implies that the coordination sites at axial positions for the metal T are now occupied by the organic ligand (L), two per metal (T). The spectra show a bathochromic shift for the characteristic bands of d–d transition from octahedral metal T, upon 1m2p coordination, compared with the layered precursor (Figure ). This shift enables overlapping of the less energetic band (1032 nm), assigned to the 3T2g ← 3TA2g(F) transition with a broad absorption band observed in the near-lR (1215 nm). Bathochromic shift could be attributed to electronic redistribution around the T metal as a consequence of the replacement by the organic molecule at the axial sites. On the other side, the mentioned broad absorption in the near-IR for T(L)2[Ni(CN)4] compounds is an outstanding and unique spectral feature, related to the presence of the charge-transfer transitions, a feature reported for intermolecular associations of various electron-donor/acceptor dyads. In the considered organic ligand, the electron-donor feature leads to the formation of a semioccupied orbital (SOMO) with strong π-character. The recorded electronic spectra are conclusive regarding the planar coordination for the Ni atom in the [Ni(CN)4] moiety, since the UV region exhibits distinctive intense bands at 275, 290, and 315 nm.
elements.clean_text: UV-vis spectra suggest that in the obtained precipitate the T atoms preserve the octahedral coordination, which implies that the coordination sites at axial positions for the metal T are now occupied by the organic ligand (L), two per metal (T). The spectra show a bathochromic shift for the characteristic bands of d-d transition from octahedral metal T, upon 1m2p coordination, compared with the layered precursor (Figure ). This shift enables overlapping of the less energetic band (1032 nm), assigned to the 3T2g ← 3TA2g(F) transition with a broad absorption band observed in the near-lR (1215 nm). Bathochromic shift could be attributed to electronic redistribution around the T metal as a consequence of the replacement by the organic molecule at the axial sites. On the other side, the mentioned broad absorption in the near-IR for T(L)2[Ni(CN)4] compounds is an outstanding and unique spectral feature, related to the presence of the charge-transfer transitions, a feature reported for intermolecular associations of various electron-donor/acceptor dyads. In the considered organic ligand, the electron-donor feature leads to the formation of a semioccupied orbital (SOMO) with strong π-character. The recorded electronic spectra are conclusive regarding the planar coordination for the Ni atom in the [Ni(CN)4] moiety, since the UV region exhibits distinctive intense bands at 275, 290, and 315 nm.

elements.content: Electronic spectra of layered precursor Ni(H2O)2[Ni(CN)4]·4H2O and the Ni(L)2[Ni(CN)4] compound.
elements.clean_text: 2  Electronic spectra of layered precursor Ni(H2O)2[Ni(CN)4]⋅4H2O and the Ni(L)2[Ni(CN)4] compound.

elements.content: The formed hybrid solids crystallize with a monoclinic unit cell, in the C2/m space group, with cell parameters, in Å, Mn: a = 16.642(4), b = 7.524(2), c = 7.190(5), and β = 102.40(3)°; Co: a = 16.524(3), b = 7.382(5), c = 7.061(4), and β = 101.07(3)°; Ni: a = 16.501(3), b = 7.318(2), c = 7.0099(10), and β = 100.68(3)°. The cell volume is occupied by two formula units (Z = 2). Figure shows typical XRD powder pattern for this series of solids. The structural model to be refined was prepared considering the obtained structure for analogue compounds with organic molecules as axial organic ligands for the metal T. The positions for C and N atoms in the ligand ring and for the C atom in the methyl group were derived from Fourier difference mapping using the program SHELXL. The resulting structural model was then refined using the Rietveld method to obtain the atomic positions and thermal and occupation factors. The refined structural information is available from the ; it was also deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with the CCDC file numbers indicated below. The relevant interatomic distances are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

The formed hybrid solids crystallize with a monoclinic unit cell, in the C2/m space group, with cell parameters, in Å, Mn: a = 16.642(4), b = 7.524(2), c = 7.190(5), and β = 102.40(3)°; Co: a = 16.524(3), b = 7.382(5), c = 7.061(4), and β = 101.07(3)°; Ni: a = 16.501(3), b = 7.318(2), c = 7.0099(10), and β = 100.68(3)°. The cell volume is occupied by two formula units (Z = 2). Figure  shows typical XRD powder pattern for this series of solids. The structural model to be refined was prepared considering the obtained structure for analogue compounds with organic molecules as axial organic ligands for the metal T. The positions for C and N atoms in the ligand ring and for the C atom in the methyl group were derived from Fourier difference mapping using the program SHELXL. The resulting structural model was then refined using the Rietveld method to obtain the atomic positions and thermal and occupation factors. The refined structural information is available from the ; it was also deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with the CCDC file numbers indicated below. The relevant interatomic distances are summarized in Table .

elements.content: Experimental and fitted patterns and their difference for Mn(L)2[Ni(CN)4]. Analogues patterns were obtained for T = Co, Ni (see the Supporting Information).

Reference : ⟨CO⟩ = 1.254 Å; ⟨C–O⟩ = 1.411 Å; ⟨N–CCH3⟩ = 1.442 Å.

Figure shows the atomic packing within the unit cell. The nickel atom preserves the square planar coordination corresponding to the original layered solid, while in the outer metal (T), the axial coordination positions are occupied by two organic ligand molecules. The recorded TG curves support such a model. The weight loss observed before the layer thermal decomposition corresponds to the evolution of two organic molecules considering the following formula unit, T(L)2[Ni(CN)4], for the formed hybrid inorganic–organic solids. This formula unit was confirmed from elemental chemical analyses (see the ).
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the atomic packing within the unit cell. The nickel atom preserves the square planar coordination corresponding to the original layered solid, while in the outer metal (T), the axial coordination positions are occupied by two organic ligand molecules. The recorded TG curves support such a model. The weight loss observed before the layer thermal decomposition corresponds to the evolution of two organic molecules considering the following formula unit, T(L)2[Ni(CN)4], for the formed hybrid inorganic-organic solids. This formula unit was confirmed from elemental chemical analyses (see the ).

elements.content: 1m2p is a polar molecule with a strong dipole moment, 4.1 D versus 1.85 D for the water molecule, for instance. Charge redistribution within the ligand associated with the homolitic π bond disrupting and the coordination bond formation at the O end modifies the molecule dipole moment but preserves its polar character. The T–O interatomic distance follows the order Ni < Co < Mn (Table ), which suggests that the coordination bond strength is determined by the metal polarizing power. The same order was observed for the C–O distance (Table ), in total correspondence with the inverse order found for the characteristic ν(CO) vibration frequency for each compound. The charge subtraction made by the T metal at the O atom leads to a weakening of the chemical bond between the C and O atoms, which is identified in the refined crystal structure as a larger value for the C–O interatomic distance.
elements.clean_text: 1m2p is a polar molecule with a strong dipole moment, 4.1 D versus 1.85 D for the water molecule, for instance. Charge redistribution within the ligand associated with the homolitic π bond disrupting and the coordination bond formation at the O end modifies the molecule dipole moment but preserves its polar character. The T-O interatomic distance follows the order Ni < Co < Mn (Table ), which suggests that the coordination bond strength is determined by the metal polarizing power. The same order was observed for the C-O distance (Table ), in total correspondence with the inverse order found for the characteristic ν(CO) vibration frequency for each compound. The charge subtraction made by the T metal at the O atom leads to a weakening of the chemical bond between the C and O atoms, which is identified in the refined crystal structure as a larger value for the C-O interatomic distance.

elements.content: In the interlayer region, ligand molecules from neighboring layers remain stacked in a head-to-tail fashion, through attractive dipole–dipole coupling and π–π interactions (discussed below). Intermolecular separation between the semioccupied orbital (SOMO) from 1m2p organic radicals (3.659–3.762 Å ring distance, Table ) is greater than the van der Waals limit for a radicals comprised of carbon π center (3.5 Å). This wide distance lead to a π-bonded extended system and also prevents σ dimerization, even at low temperatures as the recorded magnetic data reveal (discussed below).
elements.clean_text: In the interlayer region, ligand molecules from neighboring layers remain stacked in a head-to-tail fashion, through attractive dipole-dipole coupling and π-π interactions (discussed below). Intermolecular separation between the semioccupied orbital (SOMO) from 1m2p organic radicals (3.659-3.762 Å ring distance, Table ) is greater than the van der Waals limit for a radicals comprised of carbon π center (3.5 Å). This wide distance lead to a π-bonded extended system and also prevents σ dimerization, even at low temperatures as the recorded magnetic data reveal (discussed below).

elements.content: In the resulting 3D framework, the T[Ni(CN)4] layers are found with a rippled sheets conformation (Figure ), which is determined by the head-to-tail configuration for the neighboring ligand molecules where “the lowest energy conformation maximizes overlap of the frontier orbitals simultaneously minimizing intermolecular contacts”, a structural principle named the maximin principle by Lee.
elements.clean_text: In the resulting 3D framework, the T[Ni(CN)4] layers are found with a rippled sheets conformation (Figure ), which is determined by the head-to-tail configuration for the neighboring ligand molecules where "the lowest energy conformation maximizes overlap of the frontier orbitals simultaneously minimizing intermolecular contacts", a structural principle named the maximin principle by Lee.

elements.content: Left: Atomic packing within the unit cell. Right: Neighboring organic ligand molecules adopt a face-to-face configuration through dipole–dipole and quadrupole–quadrupole interactions.
elements.clean_text: 4  Left: Atomic packing within the unit cell. Right: Neighboring organic ligand molecules adopt a face-to-face configuration through dipole-dipole and quadrupole-quadrupole interactions.

elements.content: Figure illustrates the proposed mechanism for the ligand coordination to the layer metal (T). On the ligand–metal interaction, the carbonyl π bond homolitically disrupts and two unpaired electrons appear. As already mentioned, the observed negative frequency shift for the ν(CO) vibration (Table ) on the hybrid solid formation senses this effect. The unpaired p electron of the oxygen atom is now available to form a coordination bond with the metal z 2 (eg) orbital. This leads to certain charge redistribution within the layer; a fraction of the initial electron density on the metal z2 orbital must be displaced to the x 2 –y 2 orbital, which reduces the metal ability to subtract charge from the CN ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination-Induced Changes in 1-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone

Figure  illustrates the proposed mechanism for the ligand coordination to the layer metal (T). On the ligand-metal interaction, the carbonyl π bond homolitically disrupts and two unpaired electrons appear. As already mentioned, the observed negative frequency shift for the ν(CO) vibration (Table ) on the hybrid solid formation senses this effect. The unpaired p electron of the oxygen atom is now available to form a coordination bond with the metal z 2 (eg) orbital. This leads to certain charge redistribution within the layer; a fraction of the initial electron density on the metal z2 orbital must be displaced to the x 2 -y 2 orbital, which reduces the metal ability to subtract charge from the CN ligand.

elements.content: Proposed mechanism for the organic ligand coordination to the layer metal (T).
elements.clean_text: 5  Proposed mechanism for the organic ligand coordination to the layer metal (T).

elements.content: This ligand–metal interaction model is also supported by the refined crystal structures. The obtained C–O interatomic distance (Table ), above 1.43 Å, is typical of a single σ bond between the involved atoms. Such a model predicts a ∠T–O–C angle of 180°. The refined value results as 174° (average for the three metals), which is close to the predicted bond angle. The difference of 6° could be related to the dipole–dipole interaction between the neighboring ligand molecules. If the coordination interaction takes place preserving the nature of the carbonyl group, from a simple VSEPR approach, the ∠T–O–C angle must be close to 120°, which is quite different from the refined values (Table , Figure ).
elements.clean_text: This ligand-metal interaction model is also supported by the refined crystal structures. The obtained C-O interatomic distance (Table ), above 1.43 Å, is typical of a single σ bond between the involved atoms. Such a model predicts a ∠T-O-C angle of 180°. The refined value results as 174° (average for the three metals), which is close to the predicted bond angle. The difference of 6° could be related to the dipole-dipole interaction between the neighboring ligand molecules. If the coordination interaction takes place preserving the nature of the carbonyl group, from a simple VSEPR approach, the ∠T-O-C angle must be close to 120°, which is quite different from the refined values (Table , Figure ).

elements.content: Optimized molecular geometry for 1m2p as a free molecule (left) and upon coordination to a transition metal (a). In (b), 1m2p coordinated to T in T[Ni(CN)4] undergoes an activation which modifies C–O double bond character.
elements.clean_text: 6  Optimized molecular geometry for 1m2p as a free molecule (left) and upon coordination to a transition metal (a). In (b), 1m2p coordinated to T in T[Ni(CN)4] undergoes an activation which modifies C-O double bond character.

elements.content: The pure dipolar interaction between the layer and the ligand molecule must also be discarded because this is a relatively weak interaction and the obtained solids have a relatively high thermal stability (>100 °C), according to the recorded TG curves (). The expected ∠T–O–C angle for that last type of interaction is close to 154°, also different from the obtained experimental value. The proposed ligand–metal interaction model is in correspondence with the obtained T–O distance, of about 2 Å (Table ).
elements.clean_text: The pure dipolar interaction between the layer and the ligand molecule must also be discarded because this is a relatively weak interaction and the obtained solids have a relatively high thermal stability (>100 °C), according to the recorded TG curves (). The expected ∠T-O-C angle for that last type of interaction is close to 154°, also different from the obtained experimental value. The proposed ligand-metal interaction model is in correspondence with the obtained T-O distance, of about 2 Å (Table ).

elements.content: The unpaired p electron on the ligand ring must be mainly localized on the most electronegative N atom. This is consistent with the relatively large value found for the N–CCH3 interatomic distance (Table ). The recorded magnetic measurements (discussed below) provide conclusive evidence on the appearance of unpaired electrons in the molecule ring on the coordination bond formation. The proposed interaction model is summarized in Figure .
elements.clean_text: The unpaired p electron on the ligand ring must be mainly localized on the most electronegative N atom. This is consistent with the relatively large value found for the N-CCH3 interatomic distance (Table ). The recorded magnetic measurements (discussed below) provide conclusive evidence on the appearance of unpaired electrons in the molecule ring on the coordination bond formation. The proposed interaction model is summarized in Figure .

elements.content: At room temperature the three hybrid solids were found to be paramagnetic materials. The recorded values for molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) were converted to effective magnetic moment (μeff) per formula unit, considering the diamagnetism correction, according to μeff = 2.828√(χM T). The resulting values for μeff are summarized in Table . These values differ from the ones expected for five, three, and two unpaired electrons corresponding to divalent Mn, Co, and Ni in octahedral coordination. Such difference is particularly pronounced for Ni, with μeff = 8.20 μB, quite distant from the 2.8–4.0 μB range typical for this ion even considering the presence of orbital contribution. To that large value for μeff is contributing the unpaired electron on the ligand ring. In the formed 3D solid there are two ligand molecules per metal (T) which could be contributing with two unpaired electrons. The presence of these ligand unpaired electrons could explain the large values found for μeff (Table ).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

At room temperature the three hybrid solids were found to be paramagnetic materials. The recorded values for molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) were converted to effective magnetic moment (μeff) per formula unit, considering the diamagnetism correction, according to μeff = 2.828√(χM T). The resulting values for μeff are summarized in Table . These values differ from the ones expected for five, three, and two unpaired electrons corresponding to divalent Mn, Co, and Ni in octahedral coordination. Such difference is particularly pronounced for Ni, with μeff = 8.20 μB, quite distant from the 2.8-4.0 μB range typical for this ion even considering the presence of orbital contribution. To that large value for μeff is contributing the unpaired electron on the ligand ring. In the formed 3D solid there are two ligand molecules per metal (T) which could be contributing with two unpaired electrons. The presence of these ligand unpaired electrons could explain the large values found for μeff (Table ).

elements.content:
Expected and Experimetal Values for μ<sub>eff</sub> in BM at 300 K ion exptl value expected value (spin + orbital) expected value (spin only) assignment (unpaired electrons) Mn2+ 6.21 ∼5.9 5.92 7 e– Co2+ 5.25 4.1–5.2 3.87 5 e– Ni2+ 8.20 2.8–4.0 2.83 4 e–

Reference .

Per formula unit.

Figure shows the temperature dependence for μeff in the considered series of hybrid solids. For Mn and Co the value of μeff shows a slight continuous decrease on cooling, which is more pronounced below 100 K. This last behavior is attributed to the presence of a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between T metal centers through the −T–NC–Ni–CN–T– chains within the layer. For Co close to 2 K a slight but abrupt increase for μeff is observed, which was interpreted as the appearance of an incipient ferromagnetic interaction between cobalt atoms through the organic ligands. The temperature dependence for the nickel compound is quite different from that observed for Mn and Co; for Ni a pronounced decrease in the value of μeff on the sample cooling in the paramagnetic region is detected. Such behavior probably has its origin in the mentioned antiferromagnetic interaction between Ni atoms within the layer, which for this metal is particularly favorable because it has a high electron-withdrawing ability. Below 20 K the appearance of ferromagnetic ordering is accompanied by a pronounced increase for the value of μeff (Figure ). This last effect was ascribed to the cooperativity of the spin system related to the ferromagnetic interaction. A similar behavior is observed in analogous solids for Co and Ni and imidazole as organic ligand (see the ) where a ferromagnetic transition at low temperature is detected.
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the temperature dependence for μeff in the considered series of hybrid solids. For Mn and Co the value of μeff shows a slight continuous decrease on cooling, which is more pronounced below 100 K. This last behavior is attributed to the presence of a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between T metal centers through the -T-NC-Ni-CN-T- chains within the layer. For Co close to 2 K a slight but abrupt increase for μeff is observed, which was interpreted as the appearance of an incipient ferromagnetic interaction between cobalt atoms through the organic ligands. The temperature dependence for the nickel compound is quite different from that observed for Mn and Co; for Ni a pronounced decrease in the value of μeff on the sample cooling in the paramagnetic region is detected. Such behavior probably has its origin in the mentioned antiferromagnetic interaction between Ni atoms within the layer, which for this metal is particularly favorable because it has a high electron-withdrawing ability. Below 20 K the appearance of ferromagnetic ordering is accompanied by a pronounced increase for the value of μeff (Figure ). This last effect was ascribed to the cooperativity of the spin system related to the ferromagnetic interaction. A similar behavior is observed in analogous solids for Co and Ni and imidazole as organic ligand (see the ) where a ferromagnetic transition at low temperature is detected.

elements.content: Temperature dependence for the effective magnetic moment (μeff) in the considered series of T(L)2[Ni(CN)4].
elements.clean_text: 7  Temperature dependence for the effective magnetic moment (μeff) in the considered series of T(L)2[Ni(CN)4].

elements.content: According to the temperature dependence for the effective magnetic moment (μeff) versus temperature dependence (Figure ), for Co and Ni a transition to a ferromagnetic state, below 20 K, was expected. For Co the comparison of the zero-field (ZFC) and field-cooling (FC) magnetization curves does not reveal the presence of ferromagnetic transition (see the ). This evidence is supported by the absence of hysteresis in the recorded magnetization curve under an applied field magnetic field at 2 K (see the ). It seems the superexchange interaction is quite weak to generate a detectable ferromagnetic ordering. Figure shows the ZFC and FC curves for Ni where the ferromagnetic transition is detected at 10.07 K (T C). In the recorded magnetization curves versus applied magnetic field below that temperature, a hysteresis loop is observed (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: According to the temperature dependence for the effective magnetic moment (μeff) versus temperature dependence (Figure ), for Co and Ni a transition to a ferromagnetic state, below 20 K, was expected. For Co the comparison of the zero-field (ZFC) and field-cooling (FC) magnetization curves does not reveal the presence of ferromagnetic transition (see the ). This evidence is supported by the absence of hysteresis in the recorded magnetization curve under an applied field magnetic field at 2 K (see the ). It seems the superexchange interaction is quite weak to generate a detectable ferromagnetic ordering. Figure  shows the ZFC and FC curves for Ni where the ferromagnetic transition is detected at 10.07 K (T C). In the recorded magnetization curves versus applied magnetic field below that temperature, a hysteresis loop is observed (Figure ).

elements.content: Zero-field (ZFC) and applied (FC) magnetization curves for Ni(L)2[Ni(CN)4].
elements.clean_text: 8  Zero-field (ZFC) and applied (FC) magnetization curves for Ni(L)2[Ni(CN)4].

elements.content: The above-discussed large values found for μeff supposes that the organic ligand has paramagnetic character. The detected ferromagnetic ordering for Ni requires of the existence of p electrons on the ring able to participate in π–π type interaction between neighboring ligands. The electron found in the resonant condition between N and C atoms (Figure ) on the π orbital is responsible for both the ligand paramagnetic character and the π–π interaction between neighboring rings detected through the observed ferromagnetic coupling between octahedral Ni atoms. The presence of an unpaired electron in a ligand π orbital confers certain quadrupole moment to the ligand ring, which is contributing to stabilize the face-to-face configuration for the ligand molecules in the interlayers region. For Ni the smallest ring–ring distance, 3.659(3) Å, within the considered metal series was found (Table ). The ring–ring distance for the series of considered hybrid solids (Table ) is in the typical range for π–π interaction. The existence of a ferromagnetic coupling through the ring–ring interaction for Ni, which for Mn and Co is undetectable down to 2 K, was attributed to its relatively high electron-withdrawing ability (a high polarizing power). In terms of magnetic interactions, such a feature is equivalent to a larger overlapping (long-range indirect exchange) between the metal eg electrons and the ring electron density through the oxygen atom. Since the involved unpaired electrons, the p electron on the ring, and the unpaired electrons on the Ni atom have different symmetry properties, the resulting magnetic ordering is of ferromagnetic type.
elements.clean_text: The above-discussed large values found for μeff supposes that the organic ligand has paramagnetic character. The detected ferromagnetic ordering for Ni requires of the existence of p electrons on the ring able to participate in π-π type interaction between neighboring ligands. The electron found in the resonant condition between N and C atoms (Figure ) on the π orbital is responsible for both the ligand paramagnetic character and the π-π interaction between neighboring rings detected through the observed ferromagnetic coupling between octahedral Ni atoms. The presence of an unpaired electron in a ligand π orbital confers certain quadrupole moment to the ligand ring, which is contributing to stabilize the face-to-face configuration for the ligand molecules in the interlayers region. For Ni the smallest ring-ring distance, 3.659(3) Å, within the considered metal series was found (Table ). The ring-ring distance for the series of considered hybrid solids (Table ) is in the typical range for π-π interaction. The existence of a ferromagnetic coupling through the ring-ring interaction for Ni, which for Mn and Co is undetectable down to 2 K, was attributed to its relatively high electron-withdrawing ability (a high polarizing power). In terms of magnetic interactions, such a feature is equivalent to a larger overlapping (long-range indirect exchange) between the metal eg electrons and the ring electron density through the oxygen atom. Since the involved unpaired electrons, the p electron on the ring, and the unpaired electrons on the Ni atom have different symmetry properties, the resulting magnetic ordering is of ferromagnetic type.

elements.content: Magnetization curves (zoom) at 2 and 10 K under applied magnetic field.
elements.clean_text: 9  Magnetization curves (zoom) at 2 and 10 K under applied magnetic field.

elements.content: At ambient temperature and pressure, the interaction of 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone with the T[Ni(CN)4] leads to the molecule activation, which involves the homolytical disruption of its carbonyl π bond. The now available unpaired electron on the oxygen atom is used to form a coordination bond with the metal T at the layer, while the carbon-atom electron maintains its unpaired condition, delocalized on the C–N fragment of the ring. This unpaired electron is responsible for the molecule paramagnetic character and for the large μeff values found per formula unit for the formed 3D solids. In the interlayers region neighboring ligand molecules interact through their dipole and quadrupole moments to form a sandwich, head-to-tail configuration. Through such interactions within neighboring layers, ligand molecules are found forming linear chains, parallel to the layers system. The π–π coupling between ligand rings supports the observed ferromagnetic interactions between T metals on neighboring layers, which for Ni has a T C value of 10.07 K. The proposed model for 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone activation and the resulting organic ligand coordination to the metal centers (T), through a simple O–T σ bond, is supported by the recorded IR and the refined crystal structures. It seems that the acidic Lewis T sites available on the layer promote the carbonyl π bond rupture.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

At ambient temperature and pressure, the interaction of 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone with the T[Ni(CN)4] leads to the molecule activation, which involves the homolytical disruption of its carbonyl π bond. The now available unpaired electron on the oxygen atom is used to form a coordination bond with the metal T at the layer, while the carbon-atom electron maintains its unpaired condition, delocalized on the C-N fragment of the ring. This unpaired electron is responsible for the molecule paramagnetic character and for the large μeff values found per formula unit for the formed 3D solids. In the interlayers region neighboring ligand molecules interact through their dipole and quadrupole moments to form a sandwich, head-to-tail configuration. Through such interactions within neighboring layers, ligand molecules are found forming linear chains, parallel to the layers system. The π-π coupling between ligand rings supports the observed ferromagnetic interactions between T metals on neighboring layers, which for Ni has a T C value of 10.07 K. The proposed model for 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone activation and the resulting organic ligand coordination to the metal centers (T), through a simple O-T σ bond, is supported by the recorded IR and the refined crystal structures. It seems that the acidic Lewis T sites available on the layer promote the carbonyl π bond rupture.

elements.content: XRD patterns, IR and UV–vis spectra, TG curves, and tables of refined and calculated structural parameters for the hybrid materials under study. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. The refined structural information is also deposited at Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with the CCDC file numbers : Mn(L)2[Ni(CN)4]; : Co(L)2[Ni(CN)4]; and : Ni(L)2[Ni(CN)4].

metadata.title:
1‑Methyl-2-Pyrrolidone: From Exfoliating Solvent
to a Paramagnetic Ligand
